thread.title: Guide to the Anne Arundel County Fair
thread.title_full: Guide to the Anne Arundel County Fair

author: Jennifer Ginn
title: Guide to the Anne Arundel County Fair
text:
Guide to the Anne Arundel County Fair Caption Anne Arundel County Fair Matthew Cole, Staff Bright lights, cotton candy, and spinning rides draw folks to the midway at the annual Anne Arundel County Fair in Crownsville Wednesday evening. Bright lights, cotton candy, and spinning rides draw folks to the midway at the annual Anne Arundel County Fair in Crownsville Wednesday evening. (Matthew Cole, Staff) Caption Anne Arundel County Fair Matthew Cole, Staff 2013 Poultry Princess Jennifer Eisner, 11, of Annapolis lends a hand to incoming Poultry Princess Haley Reaney, 14, from Pasadena (L)with her bandolier at the annual Anne Arundel County Fair in Crownsville Wednesday evening. 2013 Poultry Princess Jennifer Eisner, 11, of Annapolis lends a hand to incoming Poultry Princess Haley Reaney, 14, from Pasadena (L)with her bandolier at the annual Anne Arundel County Fair in Crownsville Wednesday evening. (Matthew Cole, Staff) See more galleries By Jennifer Ginn Correspondent 
An annual tradition that got its start in the early 1950s, the Anne Arundel County Fair offers five full days and nights of wholesome family fun. Running Sept. 16 through 20 at the fairgrounds on Generals Highway, the county fair features carnival rides, camel and pony rides, pig races, square-dancing, a talent show, tractor pulls, pie-eating contests, live animal exhibits and musical performances. Caption Anne Arundel County Fair tractor pull By Joshua McKerrow, Staff Donald Butler of Bryantown smiles behind the wheel after driving in a tractor pull at the Anne Arundel County Fair. Donald Butler of Bryantown smiles behind the wheel after driving in a tractor pull at the Anne Arundel County Fair. (By Joshua McKerrow, Staff) Caption Anne Arundel County Fair tractor pull By Joshua McKerrow, Staff Donald Butler of Bryantown tears up the dirt track in a tractor pull at the Anne Arundel County Fair. Donald Butler of Bryantown tears up the dirt track in a tractor pull at the Anne Arundel County Fair. (By Joshua McKerrow, Staff) See more galleries 
Entertainment will abound at this year's fair. Each day of the fair, master woodcarver Ben Risney will use the tools of his trade to create large-scale, animal-inspired art. There will be a barnyard review that combines magic, music and comedy. Bands, dancers, comedy shows and children's performers are also on the schedule. 
The second annual Arundel's Got Talent contest kicks off on the upper stage at 7 p.m. Thursday. Then on Friday night, take part in a dance party with six-piece band Oracle at the upper pavilion from 7 to 10:30 p.m. On the lower stage, New Odyssey entertains with three musicians who play 30 different instruments at 8 p.m. Saturday night.
